Additional Bus Stops Starting Monday

Starting on Monday (9/14/2020) the Clarkston School District will reinstate our normal bus routes and bus stops we used prior to COVID-19. Bus stops will return to the one mile radius pick up instead of the COVID 1.5 mile radius pick up that started in August.

If you drive your children to school or if they walk please feel free to continue to do that as you wish. As a precautionary measure, if we see a spike in the number of positive COVID-19 cases, or if we see the buses move to more than 50% capacity, we may have to return to the COVID 1.5 mile radius pick up.

For all K-8 students riding in the morning, please be prepared for a bus arrival at your regular stop 10 minutes later than normal. Special Education stops are not affected by these changes. Please contact your school’s front office for additional clarification.

Thank you!

CLARKSTON SCHOOL DISTRICT TO PROVIDE FREE MEALS FOR ALL KIDS AGES 1-18

Starting Tuesday, September 8, 2020, we will be providing FREE meals for ALL kids ages 1-18. The USDA announced just this week that they are extending funding on emergency feeding programs (like the Emergency Summer Food Service Program) through December 2020 to help schools get food to kids.

Each school will have a designated meal pick-up time and area for kids who are not currently in school. Parents may pick up meals for their child if this works better for them. They do not have to be enrolled at the school to pick up a meal, and both breakfast and lunch can be picked up at the same time. Please call the school that you are interested in getting meals from to find out where and what time to pick up the meals.

We are thankful for the opportunity to serve our community. Please contact Amy Kimberling at 509-769-6346 or kimberlinga@csdk12.org with any other program questions.

CLARKSTON SCHOOL DISTRICT HONORS THEIR SCHOOL LUNCH HEROES

Between preparing healthy food, adhering to strict nutrition standards, navigating student food allergies, and offering service with a smile, Clarkston School District nutrition professionals have a lot on their plate. To celebrate their hard work and commitment, Clarkston schools will celebrate School Lunch Hero Day on May 1. This day, celebrated annually since 2013, was designated by The School Nutrition Association and Jarrett Krosoczka, author of the “Lunch Lady” graphic novel series. School Lunch Hero Day provides an opportunity for parents, students, school staff, and communities to thank those who provide healthy meals to nearly 30 million of America’s students each school day.

What is the 2020 Census?

The 2020 Census counts every person living in the 50 states, District of Columbia, and five U.S. territories. Every year, billions of dollars in federal funding go to hospitals, fire departments, schools, roads, and other resources based on census data. Each home will be receiving an invitation to respond to a short questionnaire. We ask that when you receive this invitation, please take a brief moment to respond (online, phone, or by mail.) Each person counted represents approximately $2,000 each year and $20,000 over a decade! Your count matters! More information regarding the United States Census 2020 can be found at https://2020census.gov/en/what-is-2020-census.html

Clarkston DECA attended the 2019 Ultimate DECA Power Trip Leadership Conference in Washington, DC. November 13-17, 2019. Twelve 3rd and 4th year DECA members attended this leadership conference which featured two nationally acclaimed speakers, learning labs, and college and career exhibits, as well as touring the many sights of Washington DC. Students and advisors were fortunate to meet with the Representative from the 5th District, Cathy McMorris Rogers to discuss the committees on which she is serving and how that affects Washington State, and then received a personal tour of the Capitol Building. DECA students who attended were: Jenna Allen, Wyatt Auer, Esther Dotson, Avery Elmore, Gia Gonzales, Emily Haddock, Jacey Hernandez, Nicolas Noland, Jacob Nissen, Nicholas Scholfield, Emerson Snyder, and Airyl Sobotta with Advisors Lynn Carey and Margie Denton.

We encourage you to stop by Walmart on Saturday to help FFA achieve their goal of filling a 12-foot livestock trailer with items to assist families in need. Let’s help ensure that families in our community have the basics going into the holiday season and that all children have a gift to open Christmas day.

CHS CAREER AND TECHNICAL EDUCATION INSTRUCTORS ARE MAKING CONNECTIONS

On October 4, 2019, the Clarkston High School Career and Technical Education instructors took advantage of the district's professional development day to meet with local industry and business leaders. Their goal was to make face to face connections within our local community to determine what current labor needs are and how they can better prepare our students to enter the workforce. Instructor Cami Browne stated, "It is important for teachers to see firsthand opportunities that are available to our students. Our goal as a district is to ensure that our students have the skill set to help them succeed wherever life takes them, whether that is a four year program, a two year program, apprenticeship, or directly into the workforce." On Friday, CHS CTE staff met with the following businesses: PK Metal, Seekins Precision, Schweitzer Engineering, Inland Cellular, Maurices, and Pier 1.

OCTOBER IS DISABILITY AWARENESS HISTORY MONTH!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUqFeg9pFLg

Did you know…
Washington successfully passed a bill that established October as “Disability History Month” in all public schools. In passing the bill, the legislature stated that “recognizing disability history will inspire students with disabilities to feel a greater sense of pride, reduce harassment and bullying, and help keep students with disabilities in school.”

It is important for people to understand that people with disabilities are more alike than different. For children, this is especially important because attitudes develop during childhood by watching and listening to peers, teachers and family. Schools, clubs and youth groups are ideal places to increase knowledge about people with disabilities and to foster positive attitudes about them. "Inclusion is within everyone's ability!"

Kindergarten Registration for the Clarkston School District is open now through May 6th for children who will be age 5 by August 31, 2019.

To register your child for kindergarten you will need to bring proof of residency, your child's birth certificate, and immunization record to the school he/she will be attending in the fall. If you are unable to provide this information, please contact the building Homeless Liaison. Office hours are 9AM to 3PM, Monday through Friday.

When you register your child for kindergarten you will make an appointment for Kindergarten Round-Up. The Round-Up will take place May 14th through May 17th at the Clarkston School District Office, 1294 Chestnut Street.

Round-Up activities determine a child's readiness for kindergarten and help teachers to plan for the upcoming year. Activities will be in the areas of: hearing/vision, gross and fine motor skills, concepts, and speech/language. Round-Up activities will take approximately 45 minutes.

If you have questions, please contact Di Howell at 509.769.5541.

This year's DECA Takeover involves 127 students divided among eight area businesses including: Albertsons, Starbucks, McDonald's, Taco Time, Gateway Golf, Tender Care Children’s Center, Orange Hippo Bakery and Kenzie’s Koffee’s two locations. In addition to area businesses, DECA students are also completing job shadow experiences in the health, education, manufacturing, and financial industries.

DECA is an association of marketing students, an international organization that allows students to learn about all the different aspects of marketing and business. The DECA Takeover day is a great experience for employees and students alike. Albertson’s will run in-store special sales in each of its departments.
